verses.text: Great are your judgments and hard to explain; therefore, untrained souls go astray.
verses.comment: This highlights the wisdom and depth of God's judgments, which often surpass human understanding. See also Romans 11:33 where Paul marvels at the mystery of God's wisdom.

verses.text: For when lawless men thought to oppress your holy nation, they themselves were imprisoned by the darkness, chained by long night, confined under their own rooftops, excluded from your eternal providence.
verses.comment: Refers to the Egyptian plagues, especially the plague of darkness (Exodus 10:21-23). The theme shows that evil returns upon the heads of those who practice it.

verses.text: They thought that their secrets would shield them; hidden under a dark covering of forgetfulness, they were scattered, terribly alarmed and filled with hallucinations.
verses.comment: The Egyptians, in their arrogance, believed they were secure. The text emphasizes that nothing is hidden from God. Compare with Psalm 73:19, where human pride is brought to nothing.

verses.text: For haunted by terrifying apparitions, they lay paralysed, and their spirits collapsed, for sudden and unexpected fear overwhelmed them.
verses.comment: This describes supernatural fear, reminiscent of the Passover night. There is a spiritual principle here: when separated from God's grace, terror follows.

verses.text: Wherever they hid, under lock and key, they remained prisoners of fate, for even the smallest breeze brought them terror, and the voices of unseen creatures filled them with dread.
verses.comment: Despite their physical protections, they could not defend themselves from God's divine judgment. This alludes to the ultimate insufficiency of relying on human strength over divine providence.

verses.text: Even the crash of falling objects or the rustling of animals unseen made them faint with fear, thinking the worst was coming.
verses.comment: Their overwhelming fear demonstrates the power of conscience and guilt when one stands opposed to the truth and justice of God.

verses.text: The very air, which is nothing, was brilliant and illuminated to all—but for them, it was filled with unspeakable apparitions; they were seized by fear that had no form or reason.
verses.comment: Light and darkness are common biblical images for knowledge vs. ignorance, truth vs. error. Here, darkness represents spiritual blindness due to sin.

verses.text: But while all strength failed them, the glance of fire did not give light, nor did the bright flames of the stars shine, nor did any lamp illuminate that terrible night.
verses.comment: This recalls the supernatural affliction of darkness in Egypt, confirming God's sovereignty over all creation, even the sources of light.

verses.text: Only fires of terror appeared to them, and in their desperation, they thought the world itself was coming to an end.
verses.comment: The terror of judgment day is foreshadowed here, a theme later expanded in the Gospels about the end times (Matthew 24:29).

verses.text: Wickedness is always cowardly, and when condemned by itself, it testifies within about its own punishment; a troubled conscience always imagines even more severe outcomes.
verses.comment: This verse speaks of the moral law written on the heart (Rom. 2:15). The concept of an accusing conscience forms the basis for later Christian understandings of conviction of sin and the need for grace.

verses.text: Fear is nothing but yielding up the help of reason, and when hope is lacking in the interior mind, the more weakened becomes the soul.
verses.comment: This points to the transformative power of trust in God to overcome fear. The New Testament echoes that 'God did not give us a spirit of terror, but of power, love, and self-control.'

verses.text: The heavier the expectations, the more they collapse, for the deeper within lies their uncertainty, the greater their outward fear.
verses.comment: The inward condition of the heart determines how one reacts to trials. This is a spiritual principle foundational for understanding later Christian teachings on interior transformation.

verses.text: They slept the same sleep as death itself, driven from the very depths of Hades, stunned by their fears, often even being shaken out of sleep by terrifying nightmares.
verses.comment: Death, sleep, and Hades are poetic expressions of despair. The intervention of God shatters natural expectations and self-sufficiency.

verses.text: Reports of terrors greater than what was really there haunted them, and so paralysed were they that no one could protect themselves from what surrounded them.
verses.comment: The experience of terror beyond ordinary reason highlights the reality of supernatural judgment. Fear without God leads to paralysis.

verses.text: Without the protection of wisdom, they were struck down by mere animals, even snakes slithering out of holes, and perished in fear, refusing to look at the very air they could not escape.
verses.comment: The loss of wisdom, a central biblical theme, is shown as a protection against evil. Echoes the lessons of Proverbs and Exodus plagues.

verses.text: Wickedness, condemned by its own witness, is cowardly by nature; when pressed by a troubled conscience, it always expects worse punishment.
verses.comment: Reiterates the theme that an evil conscience brings judgment upon itself. This is developed in both wisdom literature and Paul’s letters.

verses.text: For fear arises from expectation; in giving less credence to the evidence of reason, men become even more frightened by invisible things.
verses.comment: Fear that rejects reason is the opposite of the peace given through faith and the order provided by divinely established tradition and teaching.

verses.text: Throughout the night—whether a breath of wind, or a melodious song of birds among thick branches, or the rush of running water, or the crash of falling rocks, or the sound of swift feet, or the howl of wild animals, or an echo bouncing off a hollow valley—in all these terrors, men fell down and covered their faces.
verses.comment: Nature itself became a source of terror in the absence of trust in God. The reaction shows the effect of a heart unmoored from assurance in divinely-given revelation.

verses.text: For the whole world was illuminated with brilliant light, and went about its work unhindered, but over them alone spread a deep dark night, an image of the darkness that was later to overtake them. Still heavier than the darkness, was the burden of their own conscience.
verses.comment: There is a contrast between the righteous and the unrighteous, reminiscent of the Exodus where Israel had light and Egypt had darkness (Ex. 10:22-23). Spiritually, this foreshadows the separation between God's people and those still in darkness (1 John 1:5-7).

verses.text: They thought their own secrets would conceal them, but they were scattered, terrified and overcome by illusory fears.
verses.comment: The futility of hiding from God is a repeated biblical theme; compare with Adam and Eve in Genesis 3, and with prophetic warnings to Israel.

verses.text: Thus, those upon whom your anger was not laid low, were surprised by extraordinary terror and were pursued by the darkness already upon them.
verses.comment: The righteous were protected; the wicked were justly given over to their fears. This supports the biblical narrative that salvation and security come only through belonging to the people of God—through faith, right worship, and the inheritance of divine revelation.
